questions.answer_description: In this exhibit the OSPF domain is redistributed into the EIGRP 100 domain so Network B will present into Router R-4. However, the Network A network will not be seen on router R-4 (The bottom router which is improperly labeled Network B) because EIGRP 50 was not redistributed into EIGRP 100.
questions.answer: D. neither Network A nor Network B
questions.answer_ET: D. neither Network A nor Network B

questions.question_text: When an EIGRP topology change is detected, what is the correct order of events when there is a FS?

choices.C: The neighbor adjacency is deleted. Routes enter the Active state and the feasible route is used. DUAL is notified. Remove all topology entries learned from that neighbor.
choices.B: DUAL is notified. Remove all topology entries learned from that neighbor. The neighbor adjacency is deleted. Routes enter the Active state and the feasible route is used.
choices.D: DUAL is notified. The neighbor adjacency is deleted. Remove all topology entries learned from that neighbor.
choices.A: The neighbor adjacency is deleted. The feasible route is used. DUAL is notified. Remove all topology entries learned from that neighbor.

discussion.content:
D. 
DUAL is notified. 
The neighbor adjacency is deleted. 
Remove all topology entries learned from that neighbor. 
The Feasible route is used.

questions.answer_description: If a packet is not received before the expiration of the hold time, the neighbor adjacency is deleted, and all topology table entries learned from that neighbor are removed, as if the neighbor had sent an update stating that all the routes are unreachable. If the neighbor is a successor for any destination networks, those networks are removed from the routing table, and alternative paths, if available, are computed. This lets the routes quickly reconverge if an alternative feasible route is available.

questions.answer: F. All the routes are in the passive mode because R1 is in the query process for those routes.
questions.answer_ET: F. All the routes are in the passive mode because R1 is in the query process for those routes.

choices.C: The best path for R1 to reach the 192.168.1.48/28 prefix is via 192.168.1.66.
choices.D: 40512000 is the advertised distance (AD) via 192.168.1.66 to reach the 192.168.1.48/28 prefix.
choices.B: R1 will load balance between three paths to reach the 192.168.1.48/28 prefix because all three paths have the same advertised distance (AD) of 40512000.
choices.E: All the routes are in the passive mode because these routes are in the hold-down state.

questions.answer_description: It can be determined that AS 200 is used, from the fact that the IS-IS process ID is labeled as 200. The best path to reach the network 192.168.1.48/28 is the first one displayed in the routing table. This can be further demonstrated by the fact that the metric is less than the alternative route, via serial 0. Finally, the AD can be found by viewing the second number within the parentheses, which in this case is 40512000.

choices.B: the eigrp stub command on router RTB
choices.C: the eigrp stub connected command on router RTA
choices.D: the eigrp stub connected command on router RTB
choices.A: the eigrp stub command on router RTA
choices.E: the eigrp stub receive-only command on router RTA

questions.answer_ET: F. the eigrp stub receive-only command on router RTB
questions.answer: F. the eigrp stub receive-only command on router RTB
questions.answer_description: This is a hub and spoke network, so EIGRP stub receive-only command on RTB will restrict the router from sharing its routing information with RTA.

discussion.content: F. the eigrp stub receive-only command on router RTB

choices.C: 192.168.1.0 is a redistributed route into EIGRP.

questions.answer: D. 192.168.1.0 is equal path load balancing with 172.16.1.0.

discussion.content: C. 192.168.1.0 is a redistributed route into EIGRP.

questions.answer_ET: D. 192.168.1.0 is equal path load balancing with 172.16.1.0.
